title: Part A
stimulusHtml:
Part (a): 1 point
One point is earned for correctly identifying the PRI as Mexico’s historically dominant party AND for identifying Mexico’s current party system as multiparty.
descriptions:
The student attempted to answer, but response contains no relevant content.

1 point is earned for correctly identifying the PRI as Mexico’s historically dominant party AND for identifying Mexico’s current party system as multiparty.

The student responses provide the correct identification

1 point is earned for correctly identifying the PRI as Mexico’s historically dominant party AND for identifying Mexico’s current party system as multiparty.

title: Part B
stimulusHtml:
Part (b): 2 points
One point is earned for EACH correct description of a reform that facilitated Mexico’s transition away from a dominant party system.  
Acceptable descriptions include:

  • The establishment of the IFE

  • More autonomy and strength for the IFE

  • The elimination of el dedazo

  • A series of electoral reforms to encourage minority representation 

  • Privatizing state-owned corporations, decreasing patronage

  • Decentralization reform, reducing PRI power at the subnational level

  • Zedillo’s decision to use primaries for the PRI

title: Part C
stimulusHtml:
Part (c): 1 point
One point is earned for correctly identifying United Russia as Russia’s current dominant party. 

Note: A response merely stating “Putin’s party” does not earn a point.

The student attempted to answer, but response contains no relevant content.

One point is earned for correctly identifying United Russia as Russia’s current dominant party. 

Note: A response merely stating “Putin’s party” does not earn a point.

The student accurately provided an identification.

One point is earned for correctly identifying United Russia as Russia’s current dominant party. 

Note: A response merely stating “Putin’s party” does not earn a point.

title: Part D
stimulusHtml:
Part (d): 2 points
One point is earned for EACH correct description of a reform that allowed Russia to establish a dominant party system. 

Acceptable descriptions include:

  • Increasing the threshold

  • Instituting election rule changes that encourage dominant party selection by candidates

  • Eliminating gubernatorial elections or appointment of governors

  • Creating unequal access to media

  • Raising registration requirements for parties

  • Allowing only legally registered parties to run for office

  • Using selective court decisions to disqualify candidates

title: Part E
stimulusHtml:
Part (e): 2 points

One point is earned for a correct explanation of how a dominant party can promote political legitimacy. 
Acceptable explanations include:

  • Promotes stability

  • Brings about policy continuity

  • Creates more efficient policymaking, reduces gridlock

  • Gains a majority of votes in an election

  • Boosts nationalism

  • Creates a better investment environment

  • Enacts necessary reforms

One point is earned for a correct explanation of how a dominant party can hinder political legitimacy.  

Acceptable explanations include:

  • Limits competitiveness or voter choice

  • Increases chances for authoritarianism

  • Undermines checks and balances

  • Reduces representativeness or popular voice

  • Undermines the opposition 

  • Encourages corruption
